author: racytech
content: Where I can read about CREATE3 and CREATE4?

author: merkleplant
content: for create3 you read more [here](https://github.com/0xSequence/create3/) in the initial repo from 0x. [Solmate](https://github.com/transmissions11/solmate/blob/main/src/utils/CREATE3.sol) has an, imho, cleaner implementation though.

author: rodiazet
content: If you mean new instructions from EOF you can find it here https://notes.ethereum.org/@ipsilon/mega-eof-specification

author: whileydave
content: Hey all, I did a bit of a write up on the EOF [here](https://whileydave.com/2023/10/19/digging-into-the-evm-object-format-eof/).  Mostly this is just me working through the challenges and trying to understand it all.  Anyway, interested in your thoughts.  Happy to fix anything that's wrong, etc.

author: whileydave
content:
>  I would guess there are contracts where it is impossible to determine this statically (depending on the byte chosen for the new opcode).
There is a lot that could be done to track branch destinations flowing through the stack, memory and storage.  Its not clear how far that could be pushed.  But, there are situations which are definitely impossible.  For example, if a branch destination was returned from a `call` or provided as call data.

But, really, I'm looking for clear evidence this approach absolutely could not work.  The answer seems to be: *static analysis is probably not good enough to check all jump destinations*.  But isn't there anything stronger we can say?

author: _shemnon
content: Most of the discussion on the jumpdest immediate masking occured 4 years ago.  Here's a good ethereum-magicians thread - https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/eip-663-unlimited-swap-and-dup-instructions/3346/10

author: whileydave
content: Ta, I will check that out

author: _shemnon
content: "Its unclear whether any of these breaking changes caused any significant problems for existing on-chain contracts." - Constantinople was canceled and net gas metering was removed from petersburg because of costing changes

author: _shemnon
content: EIP-2200 was the fixed variant of net gas metering

author: whileydave
content: Ok, I can put something in about that.

author: _shemnon
content: There were a couple of deployed contracts that broke because of it. Similarly the costing increases of Tangeine whistle broke some contracts, which EIP-2929 fixed via out-of-vm account warming.  That was 5 years ago and I lost the reference to the specific contracts.  Google may help, but some of it was on that old git based chat channel.

author: whileydave
content: Ok, well be great to collect more evidence for the record.  I can try and dig out some of that stuff

author: _shemnon
content: It was driven by older versions of solidity that by default hard coded some gas amounts in some contracts calls based on some huristics that IIRC related to if it was detecing a "pay only" transaciton.

author: _shemnon
content: also a reserved stiped relating to the amount of gas needed to call SSTORE, used for call failures.

author: whileydave
content: So, like `if gas == fixed amount` then do something specific?

author: _shemnon
content: No, it was limiting the gas it would send to the call.

author: whileydave
content: ah yeah, only sending exactly `2300` or something?

author: _shemnon
content: Recollection is hazy, FEM website may have more details.
